metadata.source_pdf: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Impleadment of the Commissioner of Customs as a proper party in the present suit under Order 1 Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
Infringement of intellectual property rights by the defendant under the Custom Intellectual Property Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007.
Seizure of goods by the Customs Authorities under Section 110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962, and liability for confiscation under Section 111(d).
Violation of paragraph 2.3 of the Foreign Trade Policy, 2015-20 by the defendant.
Necessity and propriety of the Commissioner of Customs as a party to the suit for adjudication of the present dispute.
Right of the plaintiff to choose the persons against whom they wish to litigate as dominus litis.
Applicability of Rule 11 of the Customs Rules regarding confiscation and destruction of infringing goods.
Effect of the pendency of the present suit on the proceedings under the IPR Enforcement Rules.
Whether the Commissioner of Customs can proceed under the IPR Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the present suit.
Interplay between the Customs Act, 1962, and the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in relation to impleadment and intellectual property rights.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Background:**
The case, CS(COMM) 835/2018, was filed in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, with Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and Anr. as the plaintiffs, and Syt Solutions Pvt. Ltd. as the defendant. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendant had infringed on their intellectual property rights by importing goods that violated the Custom Intellectual Property Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007. The defendant had imported 9,644 pieces of goods, which were seized by the Commissioner of Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Sahar, Andheri (East), Mumbai, under Section 110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962.

**Legal Issues:**
The Commissioner of Customs (General) filed an application, I.A. 3096/2020, seeking impleadment in the present suit as a proper party. The application was based on the grounds that the imported goods had infringed on the plaintiff's intellectual property rights and were liable for confiscation under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962. The plaintiffs and the defendant opposed the application, arguing that the applicant was neither a necessary nor a proper party for the adjudication of the present suit.

**Arguments:**
The plaintiffs argued that the present suit had been filed on the basis of infringement of their trademarks by the defendant, and therefore, the applicant was not a necessary or proper party. They also pointed out that the applicant had asked the plaintiff about its willingness to join the proceedings, and since the plaintiff had chosen to file the present suit for injunction, the applicant could not proceed under the IPR Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the present suit.

The defendant also opposed the application, while the applicant argued that it had a legitimate interest in the proceedings as the goods had been seized and were liable for confiscation.

**Court Findings:**
The court, citing the Supreme Court's decision in Mumbai International Airport (P) Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd. (2010), observed that the plaintiff in a suit has the right to choose the persons against whom they wish to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person against whom they do not seek any relief.

The court also referred to the Supreme Court's decision in Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal (2005), which laid down the tests to determine who is a necessary party and a proper party in a suit. The court applied these tests to the present case and found that the applicant did not meet the criteria for a necessary or proper party.

**Decision:**
The court, after hearing the counsels for the parties, dismissed the application, I.A. 3096/2020, filed by the Commissioner of Customs (General) seeking impleadment in the present suit as a proper party. The court held that the applicant was neither a necessary nor a proper party for the adjudication of the present suit, as the plaintiff had chosen to file the present suit for injunction, and the applicant could not proceed under the IPR Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the present suit.

The decision was made by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal, with the digitally signed judgment dated December 13, 2022.

CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 1 of 7 
 
$~7

IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
 
                  Date of decision: 13th December, 2022 
 
+  
CS(COMM) 835/2018, I.A. 12048/2019(O-XI R-1 of CPC), I.A. 
12049/2019(for condonation of delay of 203 days in re-filing the 
application) 
 
 
WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES,  
INC & ANR 
 
 
 
 
 
..... Plaintiffs 
Through: 
Mr. Prithvi Singh and Ms. Devyani 
Nath, Advocates 
 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
SYT SOLUTIONS PVT. LTD.  
 
 
..... Defendant 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
Mr. Nakul Mohta, Advocate 
Mr. Ajay Kumar Pandey, Senior 
Panel 
Counsel 
for 
the 
applicant/custom 
in 
IA.3096/2020 
with Mr. Vikas Kumar Sharma, 
Advocate 
 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
 
I.A. 3096/2020(O.I R.10 of CPC) 
1. 
The present application has been filed on behalf of Commissioner of 
Customs (General), Air Cargo Complex, Sahar, Andheri (East), Mumbai – 
400009 seeking impleadment in the present suit as a proper party. 
2. 
The application is premised on the infringement of the intellectual 
property rights of the plaintiff in terms of the Custom Intellectual Property 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 2 of 7 
 
Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007 (hereinafter referred to 
as „IPR Enforcement Rules‟), on account of the import of goods by the 
defendant. The applicant had passed a seizure memo dated 2nd May, 2018 in 
respect of 9,644pieces of the goods imported by the defendant under Section 
110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962. It is also the case of the applicant that 
goods which have been imported into India are in violation of paragraph 2.3 
of the Foreign Trade Policy, 2015-20 and are therefore, liable for 
confiscation under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962. 
3. 
Both the plaintiff and the defendants have opposed the present 
application. Plaintiffs have filed reply in opposition to the aforesaid 
application, wherein it stated that the present suit has been filed on the basis 
of infringement of the plaintiffs‟ trademarks by the defendant and therefore, 
the applicant is neither a necessary and nor a proper party for the 
adjudication of the present suit. The applicant, vide its letter dated 24th April, 
2018, asked the plaintiff of its willingness to join the proceedings, failing 
which the applicant would release the seized goods. Rule 11 of the Customs 
Rules states that if the infringing goods have been confiscated and no legal 
proceedings are pending in relation to such goods, the applicant may 
proceed to destroy the goods after obtaining „No-Objection Certificate‟ from 
the intellectual property right holder. Since the plaintiff has chosen to file 
the present suit for injunction, the applicant cannot proceed under the IPR 
Enforcement Rules during the pendency of the present suit. Therefore, the 
applicant is neither a necessary party nor a proper party. 
4. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
5. 
The 
Supreme 
Court 
in Mumbai 
International 
Airport 
(P) 
Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd., (2010) 7 SCC 417, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 3 of 7 
 
has observed that the general rule with regard to impleadment of parties is 
that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis, may choose the persons 
against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person 
against whom he does not seek any relief. 
6. 
In Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal, (2005) 6 SCC 733, the Supreme Court 
laid down the tests to determine as to who is a necessary party and proper 
party in a suit. The relevant portions are set out below: 
“7*.  In our view, a bare reading of this provision, namely, 
second part of Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule (2) CPC would 
clearly show that the necessary parties in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale are the parties to the 
contract or if they are dead, their legal representatives as also 
a person who had purchased the contracted property from the 
vendor. In equity as well as in law, the contract constitutes 
rights and also regulates the liabilities of the parties. A 
purchaser is a necessary party as he would be affected if he 
had purchased with or without notice of the contract, but a 
person who claims adversely to the claim of a vendor is, 
however, not a necessary party. From the above, it is now 
clear that two tests are to be satisfied for determining the 
question who is a necessary party. Tests are — (1) there must 
be a right to some relief against such party in respect of the 
controversies involved in the proceedings; (2) no effective 
decree can be passed in the absence of such party. 
… 
11. As noted hereinearlier, two tests are required to be 
satisfied to determine the question who is a necessary party, 
let us now consider who is a proper party in a suit for specific 
performance of a contract for sale. For deciding the question 
who is a proper party in a suit for specific performance the 
guiding principle is that the presence of such a party is 
necessary to adjudicate the controversies involved in the suit 
for specific performance of the contract for sale. Thus, the 
question is to be decided keeping in mind the scope of the 
suit. …” 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 4 of 7 
 
7. 
In Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., 
(2012) 8 SCC 384, the Supreme Court has succinctly laid down the 
principles to be followed while deciding an application filed under Order 1 
Rule 10(2) of the CPC. Paragraph 36 in this regard is set out below : 
“36. Though there is apparent conflict in the observations 
made in some of the aforementioned judgments, the broad 
principles which should govern disposal of an application for 
impleadment are : 
 
1. The court can, at any stage of the proceedings, either 
on an application made by the parties or otherwise, 
direct impleadment of any person as party, who ought 
to have been joined as plaintiff or defendant or whose 
presence before the court is necessary for effective and 
complete adjudication of the issues involved in the suit. 
 
2. A necessary party is the person who ought to be 
joined as party to the suit and in whose absence an 
effective decree cannot be passed by the court. 
 
3. A proper party is a person whose presence would 
enable the court to completely, effectively and 
properly adjudicate upon all matters and issues, 
though he may not be a person in favour of or against 
whom a decree is to be made. 
 
4. 4. If a person is not found to be a proper or necessary 
party, the court does not have the jurisdiction to order 
his impleadment against the wishes of the plaintiff.” 
 
8. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to the prayers made in the 
plaint, which are set out below: 
“A. A decree of permanent injunction restraining the 
defendants, their partners, representatives and/or others 
acting for and on their behalf for importing, selling, offering 
for sale, advertising or otherwise dealing in infringing goods 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 5 of 7 
 
bearing the plaintiffs’ registered trademarks WESTERN 
DIGITAL,
 and/or WD under nos.1345682, 1349235 and 
1325732 in Class 9. 
 
B. 
An order of delivery up of all the infringing goods 
bearing the plaintiffs’ trademarks WESTERN DIGITAL,
 
and/or WD including packaging(s), cartons, labels, stickers, 
and/or publicity material bearing the impugned trademarks for 
the purposes of destruction/erasure. 
 
C. 
An order for damages of Rs.1,00,01,000. 
 
9. 
As can be seen from the above, no relief has been sought against the 
applicant. The entire case of the plaintiff is based on the infringement of the 
trademarks of the plaintiffs by the defendant. Therefore, it cannot be said 
that an effective decree cannot be passed in the present suit in the absence of 
the applicant. It is not even the case of the applicant that the applicant is a 
necessary party, as the present application seeks impleadment only on the 
basis of the applicant being a proper party. 
10. 
In terms of the legal position discussed above, for a person to be a 
proper party to a suit, it is to be seen whether the presence of such person 
would enable the Court to completely, effectively and properly adjudicate 
upon the issue in the case. 
11. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to Rule 11 of the IPR 
Enforcement Rules, the relevant portion is set out below: 
“11. Disposal of  infringing goods. –  
 
(1) Where upon determination by the Deputy Commissioner 
of Customs or Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case 
may be, it is found that the goods detained or seized have 
infringed intellectual property rights, and have been 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 6 of 7 
 
confiscated under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962 
and no legal proceedings are pending in relation to such 
determination, the Deputy Commissioner of Customs or 
Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case may be, shall 
destroy the goods under official supervision or dispose them 
outside the normal channels of commerce after obtaining “no 
objection” or concurrence of the right holder or his authorized 
representative. 
 
 
 
…” 
 
12. 
In terms of the aforesaid Rule, the applicant has the jurisdiction to 
determine if the seized goods are infringing the Intellectual Property Rights 
of the plaintiffs, only in the event of no legal proceedings being pending in 
relation to such determination. However, the present suit is such a legal 
proceeding in which a determination is to be made whether the goods 
imported by the defendant are infringing or not. Therefore, in terms of Rule 
11 of IPR Enforcement Rules, the applicant cannot go into the question of 
infringement till the final adjudication of the present suit. 
13. 
In the event, this Court comes to a finding that the defendant has not 
infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, the said determination shall be 
binding on the applicant and there cannot be any question of destruction of 
the infringing goods.  On the other hand, if a final determination is made by 
this Court that the goods have infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
appropriate orders shall be passed with regard to the aforesaid goods. 
14. 
In view of the discussion above, the applicant is neither a necessary 
party nor a proper party for the adjudication of the suit. There is no merit in 
the present application and the same is dismissed. 
15. 
Needless to state this is without prejudice to any other statutory 
rights/remedy of the applicant.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 7 of 7 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018 
16. 
In the order dated 5th July, 2019, the submission of the counsel for the 
plaintiff has been recorded that the present suit is a fit case for the Court to 
proceed to pass a summary judgment under Order 13A of the Code of Civil 
Procedure, 1908. 
17. 
In terms of the aforesaid order, both sides have filed their respective 
written submissions along with judgments in support thereof. 
18. 
List for hearing on 21st March, 2023. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. 
DECEMBER 13, 2022 
dk 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case CS(COMM) 835/2018 on December 13, 2022. The plaintiffs, Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and another, sued the defendant, SYT Solutions Pvt. Ltd., for intellectual property rights infringement. The Commissioner of Customs (General) filed an application for impleadment as a proper party, citing the infringement of the plaintiff's intellectual property rights under the Custom Intellectual Property Rights (Imported Goods) Enforcement Rules, 2007.

The applicant had seized 9,644 pieces of goods imported by the defendant on May 2, 2018, under Section 110(1) of the Customs Act, 1962. Both the plaintiff and the defendant opposed the application, with the plaintiff arguing that the applicant was neither a necessary nor a proper party for the adjudication of the suit. The plaintiff claimed that the suit was filed for trademark infringement and that the applicant's role was limited to confiscation under the Customs Act.

The court considered the arguments and referred to the Supreme Court's decision in Mumbai International Airport (P) Ltd. v. Regency Convention Centre & Hotels (P) Ltd. The decision on the application was made by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal on December 13, 2022. The PDF document provides further details on the case, including the proceedings and arguments presented by the parties. (Source: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on December 13, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 835/2018. The plaintiffs, Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and another, brought a suit against the defendants. The court observed that the general rule regarding impleadment of parties is that the plaintiff may choose the persons against whom they wish to litigate.

The court referred to the Supreme Court's decision in Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal (2005) 6 SCC 733, which laid down tests to determine necessary and proper parties in a suit. The tests include: (1) there must be a right to some relief against such party in respect of the controversies involved, and (2) no effective decree can be passed in the absence of such party.

The court considered the scope of the suit and the guiding principle that the presence of a party is necessary to adjudicate the controversies involved. The case involves an application for impleadment of parties, with the plaintiffs seeking relief against the defendants. The court's decision is based on the legal proceedings, facts, and arguments presented in the case. The PDF document provides detailed information on the legal proceedings, including the dates of filings and hearings. (Source: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf)

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary: According to page 3 of the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf" (2022/DHC/005588), the court discusses the rule of impleadment of parties. The Supreme Court in Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal (2005) 6 SCC 733 laid down tests to determine necessary and proper parties in a suit. Two tests are required: (1) a right to some relief against the party, and (2) no effective decree can be passed in their absence. The court also notes that a plaintiff, as dominus litis, can choose who to litigate against and cannot be compelled to sue someone they don't seek relief from. The case CS(COMM) 835/2018 is being heard in the High Court of Delhi, with a decision date of December 13, 2022.

that the plaintiff in a suit, being dominus litis, may choose the persons 
against whom he wishes to litigate and cannot be compelled to sue a person 
against whom he does not seek any relief. 
6. 
In Kasturi v. Iyyamperumal, (2005) 6 SCC 733, the Supreme Court 
laid down the tests to determine as to who is a necessary party and proper 
party in a suit. The relevant portions are set out below: 
“7*.  In our view, a bare reading of this provision, namely,

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the legal proceedings CS(COMM) 835/2018 involve Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and another party as plaintiffs, and Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd as the defendant. The case revolves around trademark infringement, with the plaintiffs seeking a permanent injunction, delivery up of infringing goods, and damages of Rs.1,00,01,000.

The court refers to the Supreme Court's judgment in Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd. (2012) 8 SCC 384, which lays down principles for deciding applications under Order 1 Rule 10(2) of the CPC. The court notes that a necessary party is one whose presence is necessary for effective adjudication, while a proper party is one whose presence enables the court to completely adjudicate upon all matters.

The applicant seeks impleadment as a proper party, but the court observes that no relief has been sought against the applicant, and the plaintiff's case is based on trademark infringement by the defendant. The court cites Rule 11 of the IPR Enforcement Rules, which pertains to the disposal of infringing goods.

The decision was made on December 13, 2022, and the document was digitally signed by Amit Bansal on December 16, 2022. The proceedings are ongoing, with the court considering the legal arguments and principles applicable to the case. (Source: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf)

nodes.summary:
According to page 4 of the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the court refers to the Supreme Court's decision in Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd. (2012) 8 SCC 384, which lays down principles for deciding applications under Order 1 Rule 10(2) of the CPC. The principles include: 
1. The court can direct impleadment of any person at any stage of the proceedings.
2. A necessary party is one in whose absence an effective decree cannot be passed.
3. A proper party is one whose presence enables the court to completely adjudicate upon all matters.
4. The court cannot order impleadment against the plaintiff's wishes if the person is not a proper or necessary party. 
The court also refers to the prayers made in the plaint, including a decree of permanent injunction restraining the defendants from importing or selling infringing goods. (Source: PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", page 4)
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 4 of 7 
 
7. 
In Vidur Impex & Traders (P) Ltd. v. Tosh Apartments (P) Ltd., 
(2012) 8 SCC 384, the Supreme Court has succinctly laid down the 
principles to be followed while deciding an application filed under Order 1 
Rule 10(2) of the CPC. Paragraph 36 in this regard is set out below : 
“36. Though there is apparent conflict in the observations 
made in some of the aforementioned judgments, the broad 
principles which should govern disposal of an application for 
impleadment are : 
 
1. The court can, at any stage of the proceedings, either 
on an application made by the parties or otherwise, 
direct impleadment of any person as party, who ought 
to have been joined as plaintiff or defendant or whose 
presence before the court is necessary for effective and 
complete adjudication of the issues involved in the suit. 
 
2. A necessary party is the person who ought to be 
joined as party to the suit and in whose absence an 
effective decree cannot be passed by the court. 
 
3. A proper party is a person whose presence would 
enable the court to completely, effectively and 
properly adjudicate upon all matters and issues, 
though he may not be a person in favour of or against 
whom a decree is to be made. 
 
4. 4. If a person is not found to be a proper or necessary 
party, the court does not have the jurisdiction to order 
his impleadment against the wishes of the plaintiff.” 
 
8. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to the prayers made in the 
plaint, which are set out below: 
“A. A decree of permanent injunction restraining the 
defendants, their partners, representatives and/or others 
acting for and on their behalf for importing, selling, offering 
for sale, advertising or otherwise dealing in infringing goods 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
According to page 5 of the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the plaintiffs, Western Digital Technologies, Inc. & Anr, are seeking relief for trademark infringement. They are seeking an order for delivery up of infringing goods bearing their trademarks, including packaging and publicity materials, for destruction or erasure. They are also seeking damages of Rs.1,00,01,000.

The court notes that the applicant is not a necessary party to the suit, as the case is based on trademark infringement by the defendant. The court refers to Rule 11 of the IPR Enforcement Rules, which deals with the disposal of infringing goods. The decision was made on December 13, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 835/2018. The PDF source provides details of the legal proceedings and arguments in the case.
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 5 of 7 
 
bearing the plaintiffs’ registered trademarks WESTERN 
DIGITAL,
 and/or WD under nos.1345682, 1349235 and 
1325732 in Class 9. 
 
B. 
An order of delivery up of all the infringing goods 
bearing the plaintiffs’ trademarks WESTERN DIGITAL,
 
and/or WD including packaging(s), cartons, labels, stickers, 
and/or publicity material bearing the impugned trademarks for 
the purposes of destruction/erasure. 
 
C. 
An order for damages of Rs.1,00,01,000. 
 
9. 
As can be seen from the above, no relief has been sought against the 
applicant. The entire case of the plaintiff is based on the infringement of the 
trademarks of the plaintiffs by the defendant. Therefore, it cannot be said 
that an effective decree cannot be passed in the present suit in the absence of 
the applicant. It is not even the case of the applicant that the applicant is a 
necessary party, as the present application seeks impleadment only on the 
basis of the applicant being a proper party. 
10. 
In terms of the legal position discussed above, for a person to be a 
proper party to a suit, it is to be seen whether the presence of such person 
would enable the Court to completely, effectively and properly adjudicate 
upon the issue in the case. 
11. 
At this stage, a reference may be made to Rule 11 of the IPR 
Enforcement Rules, the relevant portion is set out below: 
“11. Disposal of  infringing goods. –  
 
(1) Where upon determination by the Deputy Commissioner 
of Customs or Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case 
may be, it is found that the goods detained or seized have 
infringed intellectual property rights, and have been 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the court discusses the jurisdiction of the applicant to determine infringement of Intellectual Property Rights. The court states that the applicant can only determine infringement if no legal proceedings are pending, but since the present suit is a legal proceeding, the applicant cannot decide on infringement until the suit is finalized. The court also mentions that if it finds the defendant has not infringed the trademarks, the determination will be binding on the applicant, and no goods will be destroyed. The application is dismissed, stating the applicant is neither a necessary nor proper party for the suit's adjudication. The decision was made on December 13, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 835/2018. (Source: 1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf)
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005588 
 
CS(COMM) 835/2018                                                                                                      Page 6 of 7 
 
confiscated under Section 111(d) of the Customs Act, 1962 
and no legal proceedings are pending in relation to such 
determination, the Deputy Commissioner of Customs or 
Assistant Commissioner of Customs, as the case may be, shall 
destroy the goods under official supervision or dispose them 
outside the normal channels of commerce after obtaining “no 
objection” or concurrence of the right holder or his authorized 
representative. 
 
 
 
…” 
 
12. 
In terms of the aforesaid Rule, the applicant has the jurisdiction to 
determine if the seized goods are infringing the Intellectual Property Rights 
of the plaintiffs, only in the event of no legal proceedings being pending in 
relation to such determination. However, the present suit is such a legal 
proceeding in which a determination is to be made whether the goods 
imported by the defendant are infringing or not. Therefore, in terms of Rule 
11 of IPR Enforcement Rules, the applicant cannot go into the question of 
infringement till the final adjudication of the present suit. 
13. 
In the event, this Court comes to a finding that the defendant has not 
infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, the said determination shall be 
binding on the applicant and there cannot be any question of destruction of 
the infringing goods.  On the other hand, if a final determination is made by 
this Court that the goods have infringed the trademarks of the plaintiffs, 
appropriate orders shall be passed with regard to the aforesaid goods. 
14. 
In view of the discussion above, the applicant is neither a necessary 
party nor a proper party for the adjudication of the suit. There is no merit in 
the present application and the same is dismissed. 
15. 
Needless to state this is without prejudice to any other statutory 
rights/remedy of the applicant.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:16.12.2022 12:11:23
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", a court decision was made on December 13, 2022, in the case CS(COMM) 835/2018. The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case, with Amit Bansal, J. presiding. The plaintiffs, Western Digital Technologies, Inc. and another, were involved in a dispute with the defendant, Syt Solutions Pvt Ltd.

The court decision mentions that on July 5, 2019, the plaintiff's counsel submitted that the case was suitable for a summary judgment under Order 13A of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. Both parties subsequently filed written submissions and judgments in support of their arguments.

The court has listed the case for hearing on March 21, 2023. The decision does not mention any specific facts, arguments, or amounts involved in the case. The PDF document, sourced from 2022/DHC/005588, provides the court's proceedings and decisions in the case, including the digitally signed order by Amit Bansal, J. on December 16, 2022. The document consists of 7 pages, with the court decision recorded on pages 1 and 7.

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
According to page 7 of the PDF "1. WESTERN DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES VS. SYT SOLUTIONS PVT LTD.pdf", the court proceedings are as follows: 
In the case CS(COMM) 835/2018, the plaintiff's counsel submitted that the suit is fit for a summary judgment under Order 13A of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, as recorded in the order dated 5th July, 2019. 
Both parties have filed written submissions along with supporting judgments. 
The case is listed for hearing on 21st March, 2023. 
The decision was made by Judge Amit Bansal on 13th December, 2022. 
The PDF source provides the court details, including the case number and dates of decisions.
